title-group.article-title: Topical Laser Application Enhances Enamel Fluoride Uptake and Tribological Properties

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering of National Chung Cheng University, Chia-Yi, 62100, Taiwan
2Advanced Institute of Manufacturing Systems with High-tech Innovation (AIM-HI), National Chung Cheng University, Minhsiung Township, Chiayi County 62102, Taiwan
3National Minhsiung Senior Vocational of Agriculture & Industry School, Department of Bio-Industrial Mechatronics Engineering, 81 Wen-Long Village, Minhsiung, Chia-Yi County 62102, Taiwan
4Institute of Oral Medicine and Department of Stomatology, National Cheng Kung, University Hospital, College of Medicine, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, 70101, Taiwan

5Center for Micro/Nano Science and Technology, Advanced Optoelectronic Technology Center, Innovation Center for Advanced Medical Device Technology, National Cheng Kung University, Tainan, 70101, Taiwan

abstract.p: Topical fluoride treatment prevents dental caries. However, the resulting calcium-fluoride-like deposits are soft and have poor wear resistance; therefore, frequent treatment is required. Lasers quickly heat surfaces and can be made portable and suitable for oral remedies. We examined the morphology, nanohardness, elastic modulus, nanowear, and fluoride uptake of fluoride-treated enamel followed by CO2 laser irradiation for 5 and 10 sec, respectively. We found that laser treatments significantly increased the mechanical properties of the calcium-fluoride-like deposits. The wear resistance of the calcium-fluoride-like deposits improved about 34% after laser irradiation for 5 sec and about 40% following irradiation for 10 sec. We also found that laser treatments increased fluoride uptake by at least 23%. Overall, laser treatment significantly improved fluoride incorporation into dental tissue and the wear resistance of the protective calcium-fluoride layer.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Many studies have reported that fluoridation provides a cost-effective means of preventing dental decay (Ripa, 1990). Fluoridation can be achieved via a dentifrice, water fluoridation, or topical fluoride treatment. The effectiveness of a dentifrice requires good dental hygiene habits, and water fluoridation risks fluorosis (Szpunar and Burt, 1988; Marinho et al., 2003; Wong et al., 2010). Therefore, topical fluoride treatment is preferred by many dental practitioners. Children, as well as adults undergoing orthodontic treatment, especially need topical fluoride treatment. However, the calcium-fluoride (CaF2)-like deposits generated on the enamel surface during treatment are generally eroded away within days or weeks as a natural consequence of eating and chewing (Øgaard, 2001). Jeng et al. (2008, 2011) discovered that the hardness and elastic modulus of the CaF2-like deposits were approximately 0.77 and 53 GPa, respectively, while the wear depth was about 5 times higher than that of native enamel. Therefore, methods are required to increase the wear resistance of these deposits to improve the long-term effectiveness of the treatment.

A laser was first used in dentistry, in the 1960s, by Stern et al. (1966), who showed that using a ruby laser to irradiate dental enamel significantly improved its resistance to acid. Since then, many other forms of laser irradiation have been shown not only to improve the acid resistance of enamel, but also to increase fluoride uptake on the enamel surface (Yamamoto and Sato, 1980; Nelson et al., 1986; Featherstone et al., 1998; Hsu et al., 2004). Of the various forms of laser systems available, the pulsed CO2 laser is one of the most appropriate for dental health care applications (Rodrigues et al., 2004). Because the wavelengths of visible and near-infrared laser systems (e.g., Ar and Nd-YAG lasers) are only weakly absorbed by enamel (Gonzalez et al., 1996), high irradiation intensity is required to achieve the desired effect, and thus the risk of damaging the underlying pulp increases. In contrast, CO2 lasers have an infrared wavelength that is readily absorbed by the enamel surface. Consequently, the scattered energy is very low, and the laser irradiation energy is confined to the enamel surface. Furthermore, the use of a pulsed irradiation technique minimizes the accumulated energy within the enamel surface, which further reduces the risk of thermal pulp damage (Kantorowitz et al., 1998).

Although laser irradiation improves the acid resistance of enamel, it can also cause undesirable effects such as carbonization, or the formation of craters, cracks, and pores. Accordingly, various researchers have suggested that, to prevent dental caries, the ideal approach is the initial use of a topical fluoride on the enamel surface and then a laser for surface thermal treatment (Hsu et al., 2004; Rodrigues et al., 2006).

Previous investigations into the combined use of topical fluoride treatment and CO2 laser irradiation have focused primarily on the morphology, chemical composition, crystalline structure, and acid resistance of the treated enamel surface (Hsu et al., 2004; Rodrigues et al., 2006). In contrast, the nanomechanical and nanotribological properties of the CaF2-like deposits before and after laser irradiation have received relatively little attention (Jeng et al., 2008). We systematically investigated the morphology, nanohardness, elastic modulus, nanowear resistance, and fluoride uptake of fluoride-treated enamel surfaces, followed by CO2 laser irradiation for 5 sec and 10 sec, respectively.

sec.title: Sample Preparation
sec.p: Five non-carious human permanent incisors were collected with the patients’ informed consent (as approved by the IRB of National Cheng Kung University). The teeth were preserved in normal saline at 4°C and then prepared for analysis. Each tooth was cut in half. Tooth polishing is described in the Appendix.

sec.title: Topical Fluoride Treatment and Laser Irradiation
sec.p: Half of the enamel surface of each sample was covered with a Mylar strip coated with 2% neutral sodium fluoride (NaF) gel. The samples were incubated for 4 min and then rinsed under running ddH2O for 1 min as modified from previous reports (Øgaard et al., 1983). The samples were rinsed with the untreated region of the enamel held upward to prevent cross-contamination from the fluoride gel (Jeng et al., 2008).

A pulsed (5-ms irradiation, 35-ms dwell at 25 Hz) CO2 laser with a central wavelength of 10.6 µm (model 48-2, Synard, Mukilteo, WA, USA) was used for irradiation and done with a light spot (diameter, 390 µm; peak output power, 0.175 W; energy density, 732 mJ/cm2 per pulse). The laser beam was directly exposed on the prepared tooth surface for 5 and 10 sec, respectively. The laser-irradiating area of each treatment was 1 mm2. Therefore, each sample contained 6 treatment regions, namely: (1) native enamel surface (En); (2) native enamel surface irradiated by laser for 5 sec (En+L5s); (3) native enamel surface irradiated by laser for 10 sec (En+L10s); (4) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF (NaF); (5) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF and then irradiated by laser for 5 sec (NaF+L5s); and (6) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF and then irradiated by laser for 10 sec (NaF+L10s) (Appendix Fig. 1).

sec.title: Potassium Hydroxide (KOH) Extraction
sec.p: After 5 samples had been irradiated, they were agitated in 1M KOH solution (100 mL) (KOH group) for 24 hrs at room temperature (Caslavska et al., 1975) and then washed in ddH2O.

sec.title: Topography and Nanoindentation Measurements
sec.p: The topography of the 6 treatment regions on each sample was observed over an area measuring 15 × 15 µm with an atomic force microscope (AFM) (Nanoscope Dimension 3100; Digital Instruments, Santa Barbara, CA, USA) operated in a tapping mode with a scanning rate of 0.1 Hz and 512 lines per sample.
The nanohardness and elastic modulus were evaluated by a nanoindenter. The methods are provided in the Appendix.

sec.title: Nanowear Measurement
sec.p: The wear resistance of the different treatment regions was evaluated by reciprocating sliding tests under constant applied loads of 300, 350, and 400 µN. The tests, repeated 10 times in a wear area 1 × 1 µm2, used an indenter attached to the AFM and were done in contact mode at a scanning rate of 2 Hz, 256 lines per sample. The wear test surfaces of the treated specimens were relatively flat. The depth measurements were done over a 3 × 3 µm2 area, so that the worn area and the adjacent non-worn area were scanned.

sec.title: Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) and Electron Probe X-ray Microanalyzer (EPMA) Analysis
sec.p: Before SEM and EPMA observations, the specimens were dehydrated in a vacuum chamber for 100 hrs and then coated with a uniform 20-nm layer of carbon to prevent electrostatic charges. The SEM and EPMA observations were made with a microanalyzer (JXA-8500F; JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 12 kV and a probe current of 15 nA. Five different enamel surface treatment regions were analyzed by EPMA, namely: (1) native enamel surface (En); (2) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF (NaF); (3) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF and then immersed in KOH (NaF+KOH); (4) NaF-treated surface irradiated by laser for 5 sec and then immersed in KOH (NaF+L5s+KOH); and (5) NaF-treated surface irradiated by laser for 10 sec and then immersed in KOH (NaF+L10s+KOH). An EPMA was used to analyze 3 randomly selected places in each of the 5 treatments in each sample. There were 5 tooth samples examined in this study. Therefore, each treatment group had 15 test points from 5 samples.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: The differences in the mechanical properties, wear resistance, and F contents of the various treatment regions of the 10 samples were evaluated by the Bonferroni multiple-comparisons test; significance was set at p < .05 (Tepper et al., 2004).

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The Table summarizes the results obtained for the surface roughness, nanohardness, elastic modulus, and mean wear depth of the enamel surfaces subject to laser exposure with or without topical fluoride treatments.

caption.p: Enamel Surface Roughness, Mechanical and Tribological Properties Affected by Different Laser Expourse (5 characterization spots for each sample from 5 samples, n = 25.).

sec.title: Surface Topography and Roughness
sec.p: The surface roughness of laser-treated and 2% NaF-treated groups was significantly (p < .001) higher than that of the En group (Figs. 1a-1f′). There was no significant difference, however, between the En+L5s and En+L10s groups. The mean roughness (Ra), root mean square (Rq), and the maximum height (Rmax) values of the NaF+L5s and NaF+L10s treatment groups were lower than that of the NaF group (p < .05).

caption.p: Scanning electron microscope (1000× magnification) and atomic force microscope images showing characteristics of native enamel (En) surfaces subjected to different treatments: (a, a′) native enamel surface (En); (b, b′) native enamel surface irradiated by laser for 5 sec (En+L5s); (c, c′) native enamel surface irradiated by laser for 10 sec (En+L10s); (d, d′) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF (NaF); (e, e′) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF and then irradiated by laser for 5 sec (NaF+L5s); and (f, f′) native enamel surface treated with 2% NaF and then irradiated by laser for 10 sec (NaF+L10s).

sec.title: Nanohardness and Elastic Modulus
sec.p: The nanohardness of the En+L5s group was not significantly different from that of the En group. But, a 10-second application of the laser to the enamel surface significantly (p < .05) increased the nanohardness compared with that of the En group (Figs. 2a, 2b). There was no significant difference in the elastic modulus of the 3 groups.

caption.p: Mechanical and tribological properties of native enamel surface affected by different treatments. (a) Nanohardness of (En), (En+L5s), and (En+L10s) groups; (b) elastic modulus of (En), (En+L5s), and (En+L10s) groups; (c) nanohardness of (NaF), (NaF+L5s), and (NaF+L10s) groups; (d) elastic modulus of (NaF), (NaF+L5s), and (NaF+L10s) groups; (e) mean wear depth of (En), (En+L5s), and (En+L10s) groups; and (f) mean wear depth of (NaF), (NaF+L5s), and (NaF+L10s) groups.

sec.p: The nanohardness and elastic modulus values of the NaF+L5s and NaF+L10s groups were significantly (p < .05) greater than that of the NaF treatment group alone, but there was no significant difference when the NaF+L5s and NaF+L10s groups were compared (Figs. 2c, 2d).

sec.title: Nanowear
sec.p: The nanowear depths were not significantly different among the En, En+L5s, and En+L10s groups, but the wear depth was significantly (p < .001) less for the NaF+L5s and NaF+L10s regions than for the NaF group (Figs. 2e, 2f).

sec.title: Fluoride Element Concentration from EPMA
sec.p: NaF treatment produced CaF2-like crystals (diameter, 240.2 ± 27.6 nm; n = 100) on the enamel surface (Figs. 3a-3c). After CO2-laser irradiation for 5 and 10 sec, the diameters of these crystals showed significant (p < .05) time-dependent decreases in diameter to 192.1 ± 26.4 (NaF+L5s) and 138.1 ± 27.6 nm (NaF+L10s), respectively. There were about 4 to 9 CaF2-like crystals in the NaF-treated groups per observation area of 4 μm2, but only 1 to 2 crystals in the NaF-treated and laser irradiation groups.

caption.p: Magnification: (a-c, top) = 20,000×; (a-c, bottom) = 130,000×. (d) Fluoride concentration of the treatment groups and the control enamel surfaces. See Fig. 1 legend for abbreviations.

sec.p: EPMA analysis also showed that the F content of the NaF groups (0.99 ± 0.26 wt%) was approximately 2.25 times higher than that of the En groups (0.44 ± 0.18 wt%) (Fig. 3d). The F content of the NaF+KOH groups (0.60 ± 0.17 wt%) was significantly (p < .05) higher than that of the En groups. Similarly, the F content of the NaF+L5s+KOH groups (0.74 ± 0.14 wt%) was significantly (p < .05) higher than that of the NaF+KOH groups, but there was no significant difference between the NaF+L5s+KOH and NaF+L10s+KOH groups.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Previously, we reported that clinical fluoride treatment generates fluoride-containing deposits only hundreds of nanometers thick (Jeng et al., 2008, 2011). However, clinical evidence (Lowndes et al., 1996; Ishikawa et al., 2002) has confirmed that even a layer this thin is significantly protective, because it contributes to the enamel’s ability to resist cariogenic challenges. The nanometer coating significantly affects various physical, chemical, and even biological properties of the bulk materials, which suggests that the potential contribution of nanocoating to biological systems should not be overlooked. Studies of the effects of nanotribological properties on overall materials performance showed a 34% increase in the wear resistance, and CO2 lasing is anticipated to improve that percentage (Bhushan et al., 1995; Bhushan, 2007; Szlufarska et al., 2008).

We report here the first nanotribological mapping of fluoride treatment deposits and the enamel from the surface to the dentin-enamel junction (DEJ) with integrated in situ chemical composition analysis, which provides comprehensive biomechanical-chemical insight into the clinically observed protective effect of traditional fluoride treatment and into its potential limitations (Jeng et al., 2008, 2011). Lasers are among the most effective and clinically acceptable approaches for the treatment of various conditions (Miller and Truhe, 1993; Gupta and Kumar, 2011). In this study, we combined lasers with topical fluoride treatments to improve this nanomechanical clinical practice.

In addition, we found that the enamel sheaths on the tooth surface shrank after they had been irradiated and were shorter than the central enamel rods (Appendix Fig. 2). This was expected because the sheaths have a relatively higher protein content than rods (Ge et al., 2005) and protein decomposes rapidly because of the intense heat generated by laser irradiation. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images also showed that the surfaces of the irradiated specimens contained fissure-like lines and slightly melted enamel rods on the surfaces. Despite a small number of shallow fissures, the irradiated enamel surfaces were generally free of severe destructive alterations such as craters and pores. The density, width, and depth of the cracks were also significantly less than those in previous reports where higher energy lasers were used (Rodrigues et al., 2006) that might contribute to specific absorption of laser wavelengths. These results are consistent with previous findings (Hsu et al., 2004) that a pulsed, low-energy-density laser source causes only minimal damage to the enamel surface. An energy density of 732 mJ/cm2 would be enough to melt and consolidate CaF2-like deposits. We also found that laser irradiation prompted the formation of rod-like structures in the treated fluoride surface.

The nanohardness of the enamel surface significantly (p < .05) increased after 10 sec of laser irradiation. In practice, human tooth tissue is a biocomposite consisting of a reinforcement phase of mineral crystals (hydroxyapatite) and an organic matrix (primarily non-collagenous glycoprotein). Therefore, the mechanical properties of teeth were reflected by the material characteristics, composition, porosity, and microarchitecture of the reinforcement phase and matrix, as well as their interaction (Zioupos and Rogers, 2006). This contributes a potential mechanism responsible for the increased nanohardness observed in the enamel surface after laser irradiation. Laser irradiation of enamel resembles a sintering process and is accompanied by densification and grain growth (Gross and Rodriguez-Lorenzo, 2004). Densification is caused by a mass transfer that decreases the porosity and increases the grain size. However, the reduction in porosity dominates the effect of the larger grain size in determining the nanohardness, which explains the increase in nanohardness after irradiation (Gross and Bhadang, 2004).

Both CaF2-like amorphous deposits and crystals are produced on the enamel surface after topical fluoride treatment. Therefore, the nanohardness and elastic modulus of non-irradiated CaF2-like deposits are relatively low. However, they both increased significantly after laser irradiation for 5 or 10 sec. The 3-D AFM morphologies suggest that the increase in the nanohardness of the CaF2-like deposits after irradiation is a result of greater densification (i.e., lower porosity). The elastic modulus follows the same tendency because porosity has a stronger effect on the elastic modulus than does crystal size (Gross and Bhadang, 2004).

The EPMA results showed that, after KOH extraction, the fluoride content on the NaF-treated tooth surface was about 37% higher than that on the enamel surface. Demortier and Nammour (2008) argued that the uptake of fluoride on the exposed enamel surface is caused by fluoride elements migrating into the organic matrix components of the enamel crystals and forming fluoroapatites after an argon laser beam treatment (11 J/cm2 for 30 sec). We found that laser irradiation improved fluoride uptake on the exposed enamel surface by around 23%. Moreover, laser irradiation reduced the diameter and number of CaF2-like crystals, which implies that laser irradiation melted the CaF2-like crystals into the enamel. Therefore, treating the enamel surface with fluoride, followed by CO2-laser irradiation promoted greater fluoride uptake than treatment with fluoride only.

In general, we found that using laser irradiation after topical fluoride treatment increased fluoride uptake and produced significantly smaller and fewer CaF2-like crystals, as well as improving the mechanical and tribological properties of the CaF2-like deposits.

ack.p: We are grateful to the Taiwan National Science Council (grants NSC-100-2221-E-194-046, NSC-100-2120-M-194-004, NSC-100-2120-M-194-002, NSC-101-2314-B-006-048-MY3 and NSC 101-2120-M-006-008) and to the Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR) (Contract No. AOARD 114105) for supporting this research.

The authors declare no conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
A supplemental appendix to this article is published electronically only at http://jdr.sagepub.com/supplemental.
